items.content_html:
Finished reading: Human Compatible: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Control by Stuart Russell 📚 – I’ll likely have more to say about this in the weeks ahead, but for now I’ll summarize with two thoughts:

  1. The problems matter.
  2. We need non-utilitarians going after this.
items.content_text:
Finished reading: [_Human Compatible: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Control_](https://micro.blog/books/9780525558613) by Stuart Russell 📚 – I’ll likely have more to say about this in the weeks ahead, but for now I’ll summarize with two thoughts:

1. The problems matter.
2. We need non-utilitarians going after this.

items.content_html: Blogged—because I’d love for the process of building a training plan for running and cycling to respect how human lives actually work, which is to say: days are way more fungible than weeks (at least for an amateur like me)! Feature Idea: Week-Level Smart Training Plans
items.content_text: Blogged—because I’d love for the process of building a training plan for running and cycling to respect how human lives actually work, which is to say: days are way more fungible than weeks (at least for an amateur like me)! [Feature Idea: Week-Level Smart Training Plans](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/feature-idea-week-level-training-plans/)

items.content_html: Whoa: Strava informs me that last year I crossed the 10,000 lifetime miles run mark, as well as the 1,500 lifetime hours mark—and I’m probably a month’s training away from crossing 500,000 feet of lifetime climbing on my runs. 🤯 🏃🏻‍♂️
items.content_text: Whoa: Strava informs me that last year I crossed the 10,000 lifetime miles run mark, as well as the 1,500 lifetime hours mark—and I’m probably a month’s training away from crossing 500,000 feet of lifetime climbing on my runs. 🤯 🏃🏻‍♂️

items.content_html: I am trying something out: some Blog-Gardening in Public, i.e. working-in-public on (some) of my bigger essays and idea-pieces. I don’t know of many folks doing things like this, but I hope to help normalize it, because it seems good! More thoughts here.
items.content_text: I am trying something out: some [Blog-Gardening in Public](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/blog-gardening-in-public/), i.e. working-in-public on (some) of my bigger essays and idea-pieces. I don't know of many folks doing things like this, but I hope to help normalize it, because it seems good! More thoughts [here](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/blog-gardening-in-public/).

items.content_html: Just updated my website to make sure that, if you’re reading it on the website, all the things I’ve called out as “Note: …” blocks are also correctly identified as such to screen readers with aria-role and aria-label, and made it trivial to get right going forward. 🎉
items.content_text: Just updated my website to make sure that, if you’re reading it *on the website*, all the things I’ve called out as “Note: …” blocks are also correctly identified as such to screen readers with `aria-role` and `aria-label`, and made it trivial to get right going forward. 🎉

items.content_html: My wife ordered me the LEGO Saturn V model for a Christmas present, and it finally arrived yesterday. Doing this is: unreasonably fun.
items.content_text: My wife ordered me the LEGO Saturn V model for a Christmas present, and it finally arrived yesterday. Doing this is: unreasonably fun.

items.content_html: Blogged—some initial thoughts on Ought’s Elicit “AI Research Assistant” tool, which I spent some time with this evening. If that makes your skepticism radar spike, we’re the same, but I have pretty positive impressions, courtesy of wise UI design choices. Initial Notes on Elicit
items.content_text:
Blogged—[some initial thoughts][p] on [Ought](https://ought.org)'s [Elicit](https://elicit.org) “AI Research Assistant” tool, which I spent some time with this evening. If that makes your skepticism radar spike, we’re the same, but I have pretty positive impressions, courtesy of *wise* UI design choices. [Initial Notes on Elicit][p]

[p]: https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/some-notes-on-elicit/

items.content_html: I decided I want out of the game of running my own servers for websites this year, and I’m almost done—I’m moving jaimiekrycho.com to managed WordPress hosting. Real talk: finding a host to do this in a way I trust and which doesn’t make me 🤯 at the cost is… hard.
items.content_text: I decided I want out of the game of running my own servers for websites this year, and I’m almost done—I’m moving jaimiekrycho.com to managed WordPress hosting. Real talk: finding a host to do this in a way I trust and which doesn’t make me 🤯 at the cost is… hard.

items.content_html: It only took me five years (or was it six?) to finish migrating all of my old, no-longer-updated sites out of the shared hosting I used to use (…so, you know, just an extra $300 I paid over the years 🙃) but as of today I have finally shut that account down. Feels good!
items.content_text: It only took me five years (or was it six?) to finish migrating all of my old, no-longer-updated sites out of the shared hosting I used to use (…so, you know, just an extra $300 I paid over the years 🙃) but as of today I have finally shut that account down. Feels good!

items.content_html: Blogged, because I got extremely annoyed thinking about how this doesn’t exist after my long run yesterday: Product Idea: Meal Tracking for Athletes. So annoyed. 😂
items.content_text: Blogged, because I got *extremely* annoyed thinking about how this doesn't exist after my long run yesterday: [Product Idea: Meal Tracking for Athletes](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/meal-tracking-for-athletes/). So annoyed. 😂

items.content_html: Just published: a note on how lovely it is to have (more or less) what I always said I wanted back in high school and college—an orchestra in my pocket.
items.content_text: Just published: a note on how lovely it is to have (more or less) what I always said I wanted back in high school and college—[an orchestra in my pocket](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/an-orchestra-in-my-pocket/).

items.content_html:
While Obsidian’s graph view is pretty, and you can make it more useful than the baseline,1 fundamentally, if you make heavy use of links, you just end up with a mess like this. 😂

  1. Local graphs are more useful than the global graph; filters can be illuminating, etc. ↩︎
items.content_text: While Obsidian's graph view is pretty, and you *can* make it more useful than the baseline,[^1] fundamentally, if you make heavy use of links, you just end up with a mess like this. 😂 [^1]: Local graphs are more useful than the global graph; filters can be illuminating, etc.

items.content_html: I’m sort of unreasonably delighted—which is, to be clear, the best kind of delighted—by the color of this new NotNeutral mug (their 10oz Lino is just the best) which arrived today. 🤩
items.content_text: I’m sort of unreasonably delighted—which is, to be clear, the best kind of delighted—by the color of this new [NotNeutral](https://www.notneutral.com) mug (their [10oz Lino](https://www.notneutral.com/lino-coffee-mug.html) is just the best) which arrived today. 🤩

items.content_html: Finally able to spend some time with Dorico v4.3 and I love that in addition to all the feature improvements it landed, it also got some love in terms of just little bits of polish—e.g. the popovers are all just a little bit nicer-looking.
items.content_text: Finally able to spend some time with [Dorico](https://www.steinberg.net/dorico/) v4.3 and I love that in addition to all the feature improvements it landed, it also got some love in terms of just little bits of polish—e.g. the popovers are all just a little bit nicer-looking.

items.content_html: Updated my note on doing solo lines in divisi parts in Dorico this evening, after discovering a fairly key behavioral constraint!
items.content_text: Updated [my note on doing solo lines in divisi parts in Dorico](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/dorico-tip-solo-parts-in-string-sections/) this evening, after discovering a fairly key behavioral constraint!

items.content_html: Just published a new write-up on the difference between doing things like “restructuring your notes system” (puttering, even if productive) and “actually working on the essay your notes are theoretically for” (generative work).
items.content_text: Just published [a new write-up](https://v5.chriskrycho.com/journal/generative-work-and-productive-puttering/) on the difference between doing things like “restructuring your notes system” (puttering, even if productive) and “actually working on the essay your notes are theoretically for” (generative work).

items.content_html: As mentioned earlier, I’m quite bullish on Readwise and its Reader so far—but I have some pretty significant differences with the folks behind it philosophically… as I cover in this Readwise Reader-annotated version of their Reader manifesto. 😏
items.content_text: As mentioned earlier, I’m quite bullish on [Readwise](https://readwise.io/i/chris4201u) and its Reader so far—but I have some pretty significant differences with the folks behind it philosophically… as I cover in [this Readwise Reader-annotated](https://readwise.io/reader/shared/01gnxbcjfm97fyn4jyeq4msq54/) version of their Reader manifesto. 😏

items.content_html: Pretty strong first impressions here right out of the gate for Readwise—its Obsidian integration in particular is pretty neat, and I think will solve an annoyance I have had for a long time with any “web clipping”/bookmarking system: its disconnect form my notes.
items.content_text: Pretty strong first impressions here right out of the gate for [Readwise](https://readwise.io/i/chris4201u)—its [Obsidian integration](https://readwise.io/obsidian_export) in particular is pretty neat, and I think will solve an annoyance I have had for a *long* time with any “web clipping”/bookmarking system: its disconnect form my notes.

items.content_html: The one thing I would very much like from the Kobo–Pocket integration is: the ability to use the Kobo highlighting to sync highlights to Pocket. (Or to save them locally!) Yes, that would require a Pocket subscription, but it would still be excellent.
items.content_text: The one thing I would *very* much like from [the Kobo–Pocket integration](https://help.kobo.com/hc/en-us/articles/360017763753-Use-the-Pocket-App-with-your-Kobo-eReader) is: the ability to use the Kobo highlighting to sync highlights to Pocket. (Or to save them locally!) Yes, that would require a Pocket subscription, but it would still be *excellent*.

items.content_html:
Currently reading: Human Compatible: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Control by Stuart Russell 📚

I’ve been reading widely in this space for quite some time, but decided I need to brush up onn some of the books in the field, not just essays and blog posts.
items.content_text:
Currently reading: [Human Compatible: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Control](https://micro.blog/books/9780525558613) by Stuart Russell 📚

I've been reading widely in this space for quite some time, but decided I need to brush up onn some of the *books* in the field, not just essays and blog posts.

items.content_html: One thing I’ve thought about for the past few years: AFAICT no one clicks through the links I cross-post via RSS feed (of the shape [Journal]: some title). Should I do a little micro.blog “post” introducing and linking it instead? Curious what you good folks think.
items.content_text: One thing I’ve thought about for the past few years: AFAICT *no one* clicks through the links I cross-post via RSS feed (of the shape `[Journal]: some title`). Should I do a little micro.blog “post” introducing and linking it instead? Curious what you good folks think.

items.content_html: I believe the normal first post on a new micro.blog is “Hello, world!” Or maybe that’s just the first program? Well, either way, here I am: new microblog, hosted on micro.blog.
items.content_text: I believe the normal first post on a new micro.blog is “Hello, world!” Or maybe that’s *just* the first program? Well, either way, here I am: new microblog, hosted on micro.blog.
